verses.text: You are to make an altar on which to burn incense; make it of acacia wood.
verses.comment: The altar of incense holds an important role in Israel’s worship, signifying intercessory prayer (cf. Ps. 141:2; Rev. 5:8).

verses.text: It should be a square, one cubit long and one cubit wide; it is to be two cubits high. Its horns are to form one piece with it.
verses.comment: The specification of horns signifies consecration and atonement (Lev. 4:7; Heb. 9:4).

verses.text: Overlay it with pure gold—its top, its sides all around, and its horns; and make a gold molding around it.
verses.comment: Gold symbolizes holiness and glory, reserved for items set apart for God’s service.

verses.text: Make two gold rings for it under the molding on two opposite sides, to hold poles for carrying it.
verses.comment: Rings and poles allowed for the altar’s portability, a reminder of God’s presence dwelling among His people.

verses.text: Make the poles of acacia wood and overlay them with gold.
verses.comment: Gold overlay connects the altar’s sanctity with the Ark and Table of the Presence (Exod. 25:11-13).

verses.text: Place the altar in front of the veil that is before the ark of the testimony, before the mercy seat that is on the ark of the testimony, where I will meet with you.
verses.comment: The location signifies mediation and intercession. It is placed just outside the Holy of Holies, emphasizing the need for priestly intercession before God.

verses.text: Aaron shall burn fragrant incense on it every morning when he tends the lamps.
verses.comment: The daily burning of incense prefigures the continual prayers of the Church, and the ministry of priests.

verses.text: When Aaron sets up the lamps at twilight, he shall burn it, a regular incense offering before the LORD throughout your generations.
verses.comment: Incense symbolizes prayer rising to God (see Rev. 8:3-4), linking worship of Israel with Christian liturgy.

verses.text: You shall not offer unauthorized incense on it, or burnt offering, or grain offering, nor shall you pour out a drink offering on it.
verses.comment: God’s strict commands about worship protect the sacredness and purity of liturgical actions and priesthood.

verses.text: Once a year Aaron shall make atonement on its horns. With the blood of the sin offering of atonement, he shall make atonement for it once in the year throughout your generations. It is most holy to the LORD.
verses.comment: The yearly atonement anticipates the one perfect offering of Christ (Heb. 9:7-14).

verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying:
verses.comment: This marks the beginning of a new section of divine instruction.

verses.text: When you take a census of the Israelites to count them, each one must give a ransom for himself to the LORD when you number them, so that no plague may strike them when you count them.
verses.comment: The ransom payment underlines both communal solidarity and the need for atonement (cf. Matt. 20:28), highlighting sacrificial mediation.

verses.text: Each one who is counted must give half a shekel, according to the sanctuary shekel (twenty gerahs to a shekel). This half shekel is to be offered as a contribution to the LORD.
verses.comment: The sanctuary shekel standardizes offerings, prefiguring later collections for the service of God’s house.

verses.text: Everyone who is numbered, twenty years old and older, shall give the offering to the LORD.
verses.comment: The age of twenty sets an expectation of maturity and responsibility in worship.

verses.text: The rich shall not give more and the poor shall not give less than half a shekel, when you give the LORD’s offering to make atonement for your lives.
verses.comment: Equal ransom implies the spiritual equality of all before God (cf. Acts 10:34), a reality brought to fullness in New Testament worship.

verses.text: You shall take the atonement money from the Israelites and give it for the service of the tent of meeting, that it may bring the Israelites to remembrance before the LORD, to make atonement for your lives.
verses.comment: The use of offering funds prefigures the support of the Church’s worship and ministry.

verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying:
verses.comment: Another set of instructions from God begins here.

verses.text: Make a bronze basin, with its stand of bronze, for washing. Put it between the tent of meeting and the altar, and put water in it.
verses.comment: Washing was required for ritual purity, anticipating the later necessity of inward and outward cleansing (see John 13:10; 1 Pet. 3:21).

verses.text: Aaron and his sons shall wash their hands and their feet with water from it.
verses.comment: Priestly washing signifies preparation for entering God’s presence, reflected in Christian practice of ritual purity before worship and sacraments.

verses.text: Whenever they enter the tent of meeting or approach the altar to minister, to burn an offering to the LORD, they must wash with water so that they will not die.
verses.comment: The seriousness of ritual purity points toward sanctifying grace necessary to approach God, not by presumption but by humble preparation.

verses.text: They must wash their hands and feet so that they will not die. This shall be a statute forever to them, to him and his descendants throughout their generations.
verses.comment: A perpetual ordinance, signifying that the requirements of purity and preparation endure in God’s worship.

verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses:
verses.comment: A new instruction follows, continuing the theme of consecration.

verses.text: Take choice spices: five hundred shekels of pure myrrh, half as much of fragrant cinnamon—two hundred and fifty shekels—two hundred and fifty shekels of aromatic cane,
verses.comment: The recipe is precise, symbolizing divine order and the unique character of God’s worship.

verses.text: five hundred shekels of cassia, according to the sanctuary shekel, and one hin of olive oil.
verses.comment: Cassia and oil complete the anointing blend, each part with spiritual and material significance.

verses.text: Make these into a sacred anointing oil, a perfume mixed by a skilled perfumer. It will be a holy anointing oil.
verses.comment: The anointing oil, for setting apart, has great typological significance—prefiguring anointing by the Holy Spirit (Acts 10:38).

verses.text: With this oil you shall anoint the tent of meeting, the ark of the testimony,
verses.comment: Objects used in worship are set apart by anointing, symbolizing God’s presence and blessing.

verses.text: the table and all its utensils, the lampstand and its utensils, the altar of incense,
verses.comment: All sacred furnishings receive the same consecration, indicating the unified life of worship.

verses.text: the altar of burnt offering with all its utensils, and the basin with its stand.
verses.comment: Even the place of washing is anointed, reinforcing the theme of sanctification in every aspect of worship.

verses.text: You shall consecrate them, so they may be most holy; whatever touches them will be holy.
verses.comment: Contact with the holy makes one holy—a foreshadowing of the principle in sacraments and sacramentals.

verses.text: Anoint Aaron and his sons and consecrate them, so they may serve Me as priests.
verses.comment: The priests are consecrated by anointing, a clear type of ministerial priesthood later reaffirmed in Christ’s Church.

verses.text: Say to the Israelites: This will be My holy anointing oil throughout your generations.
verses.comment: Perpetual statutes of holiness see their fulfillment in the new covenant’s continual anointing with the Spirit.

verses.text: It must not be poured on anyone’s body, nor are you to make any other oil with the same formula; it is holy, and it shall be holy to you.
verses.comment: Only those set apart may receive this oil. Holy things must be protected and honored.

verses.text: Anyone who makes a blend like it or puts it on an unauthorized person shall be cut off from his people.
verses.comment: Abuse of what is sacred results in separation, signifying spiritual consequences of treating holy things profanely.

verses.text: The LORD said to Moses: Take fragrant spices—stacte, onycha, and galbanum—along with pure frankincense, all in equal amounts,
verses.comment: Incense ingredients are specified as a unique recipe for worship pleasing to God.

verses.text: and make a fragrant blend of incense, the work of a perfumer, seasoned with salt, pure and holy.
verses.comment: Salt is a sign of covenant (Lev. 2:13), pointing toward sacramental realities and God’s faithfulness.

verses.text: Grind some of it into fine powder and put it in front of the testimony in the tent of meeting, where I will meet with you. It shall be most holy to you.
verses.comment: Incense placed before the testimony prefigures intercessory prayer before God’s presence.

verses.text: The incense you make must not be made for yourselves, using its formula; you shall regard it as holy to the LORD.
verses.comment: Sacred worship must not be made common. Holiness is distinct and demands reverence.

verses.text: Whoever makes any like it to smell its fragrance shall be cut off from his people.
verses.comment: Treating holy things as merely ordinary brings judgment. The biblical pattern is reverence and awe for God’s presence and gifts.
